Class Column

  • java.lang.Object
    • Column

  • public class Column
extends java.lang.Object
    This class represents the column in the game. This class follows the game rules, so maximum of 9 columns can be created. The rule is 4 columns must have 7 cards, another 4 columns must have 6 cards, the last 1 column is left empty. Exception is thrown when more than 9 columns are created. If more columns are needed to be created, use of method resetNumOfCol() is required. After the use of method resetNumOfCol(), 9 columns with the same rule can be created again. This class also provides 2 move method that follows the game rules.

      Creates a column.
      Column(int amountOfCards, java.util.List<Card> filledCards)
      Creates a column, then add cards into the column.

      Moves the specified card(s) from this column to the end of the specified column.

      Moves the specified card(s) from this column to the end of the specified pile.
      static void resetNumOfCol()
      Sets the number of columns created to 0.
      void rotateCol()
      Moves the last element of this column to the front of this column.
      java.lang.String toString()
      Returns the string representation of this column.

      • Column

        public Column()
        Creates a column.

      • Column

        public Column(int amountOfCards,
              java.util.List<Card> filledCards)
        Creates a column, then add cards into the column.
        Parameters:
        amountOfCards - the amount of cards to add into the cardsList.
        filledCards - a list filled with cards used to add cards into the cardsList.

    • Method Detail

      • move

        public void move(java.lang.String cardStr,
                 Column toCol)
          throws InvalidMoveException,
                 InvalidCardException,
                 InvalidColException
        Moves the specified card(s) from this column to the end of the specified column. These rules must be follwed: 1. The card to be moved must be one point smaller than the last card of the column which the card move to. 2. When moving a group of consecutive right-most cards, the cards' face have to be in descending order.
        Parameters:
        cardStr - the card to be moved.
        toCol - the column which the card move to.
        Throws:
        InvalidMoveException - If the specified card moves without following the rules.
        InvalidCardException - If the specified card is invalid.
        InvalidColException - If this column is empty.

      • move

        public void move(java.lang.String cardStr,
                 Piles toPile,
                 java.lang.String key)
          throws InvalidMoveException,
                 InvalidCardException,
                 InvalidColException,
                 InvalidPileException
        Moves the specified card(s) from this column to the end of the specified pile. These rules must be follwed: 1. The card to be moved must be one point bigger than the last card of the pile which the card move to. 2. When moving a group of consecutive right-most cards, the cards' face have to be in descending order.
        Parameters:
        cardStr - the card to be moved.
        toPile - the pile which the card move to.
        key - the suit of the pile which the card move to.
        Throws:
        InvalidMoveException - If the specified card moves without following the rules.
        InvalidCardException - If the specified card is invalid.
        InvalidColException - If this column is empty.
        InvalidPileException - If the specified card's suit does not match the specified pile's suit.

      • resetNumOfCol

        public static void resetNumOfCol()
        Sets the number of columns created to 0.

      • rotateCol

        public void rotateCol()
               throws InvalidColException
        Moves the last element of this column to the front of this column.
        Throws:
        InvalidColException - If this column is empty.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns the string representation of this column. The format is same as the toString method of class java.util.AbstractCollection.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a string representation of this column.
